image.altText: A National Capital Authority blue sign on a building site marking the planned future location for a Russian Embassy.

props.synopsis: Australia passed a law in 2023 cancelling Russia's lease for a planned embassy near Parliament House, but Russia is now disputing that in the High Court.

title.children: Russia takes Australia to High Court over cancelled lease

image.altText: A police officer with arms out in front and a person in black jumper falling.

props.synopsis: New South Wales Police says it's reviewing a video circulating on social media which allegedly shows a police officer pushing a woman who then hits her head as she falls to the ground.Â

title.children: Video allegedly shows police officer pushing woman who hits head on post

image.altText: A woman in activewear, a cap and black sunglasses walks with a black guide dog on a pedestrian crossing next to construction.

props.synopsis: Footpaths in the ACT are often closed or blocked because of construction, leaving the streets obstacle-filled and difficult to navigate for people with vision impairments.

title.children: Canberra footpaths blocked by construction, making streets inaccessible

image.altText: Jenny sits next to a table, a plate of cookies on it, looking into the camera.

props.synopsis: Canberra's Parkinson's community has long been campaigning for the ACT government to employ a specialist Parkinson's nurse who can visit patients at home. The ACT government says planning is underway to create the position but a start date has yet to be confirmed.

title.children: Renewed calls for ACT specialist Parkinson's nurse

image.altText: Stephen Nutt stands in his police uniform, speaking in front of a sign that says AFP.

props.synopsis: A Chinese national has faced a Canberra court today after being arrested on Saturday and charged with foreign interference.

title.children: Chinese national charged under foreign interference laws

image.altText: Serious man wears yellow cap backwards, rust jumper, French goatee leans on a fridge looking at wedges of cheese.

props.synopsis:
High heater use, population growth and a push towards electrification has seen an uptick in unplanned power outages in Canberra this winter as the electricity network struggles to cope with demand. Â Â 

Â

title.children: Canberra's power outages leave business owners like Alex nervous

image.altText: cars splash water over the road as pedestrians try cross flooded roads and footpaths

props.synopsis: A wet finish to the year is increasingly favoured across Australia as a major climate driver emerges for the first time in three years.

title.children: Major climate driver signals wet August to December

image.altText: Two men shake hands for camera as one waves.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and French President Emmanuel Macron discuss the war in Gaza during a phone call.

title.children: Albanese and Macron speak about Gaza and agree to meet at UN summit

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Despite AUKUS and tariff doubts, State Department says US-Australia relations 'terrific'
Marles says government 'listening' to Australians on Gaza
Albanese talks Gaza and makes plans to meet with Macron at UN General Assembly

image.altText: The ASX building exterior.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is on track to have a relatively subdued start to its day despite modest falls on Wall Street overnight, as major US companies like Caterpillar revealed the impact of Donald Trump's tariff on their earnings. Follow live.

title.children: Wall St dragged lower as Trump tariffs hurt profits, ASX to open steady

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Trump says pharmaceutical tariffs could surge to 250 per cent, flags import taxes on semiconductors
Surging house prices and interest rate cuts boost REA Group's profit
News Corp's full-year profit surges 71pc, lifted by real estate listings business

image.altText: A person wearing a welding masks and gloves welds.

props.synopsis: We rank amongst the world's richest nations when it comes to personal wealth but, in terms of our economy and particularly its complexity, we sit amongst the world's poorest â and the situation is progressively getting worse.

title.children: Australia in race to wind back industrial devolution

image.altText: A middle aged man gives a thumbs up out of a car window

props.synopsis: Jeremy Rockliff, who two months ago lost the confidence of the Tasmanian parliament, is visiting the governor to ask that she recommission him as premier of a minority Liberal government.

title.children: Breaking: Rockliff arrives at Government House to ask to be recommissioned as premier

image.altText: A Centrelink/Medicare sign outside a branch.

props.synopsis: Almost a thousand jobseekers had their income support payments unlawfully terminated over two years, the federal watchdog has found, cautioning the breach likely had a "profound if not catastrophic" impact on vulnerable people.

title.children: Automatic systems unlawfully cancelled 964 jobseekers' payments, watchdog finds

image.altText: A man wearing a checked shirt with gray hair

props.synopsis: Australian musician Col Joye, the first Australian pop performer to reach number one on the local charts, has died at the age of 89.

title.children: Australian musician Col Joye dies aged 89

image.altText: Toowoomba QTU protesters

props.synopsis: Today's strike action is expected to affect more than half a million students at about 1,200 state schools.

title.children: Queensland teachers to strike over 'pretty dire situation'

image.altText: Oskar Speck in his kayak

props.synopsis: Unemployed and seeking a better life, Oscar Speck pushed his kayak into the water of the Danube River and began paddling downriver. He didn't stop until he reached Australia.

title.children: The forgotten story of the man who kayaked 50,000km around the world

image.altText: Bill and Hillary Clinton walking through a procession at Donald Trump's second inauguration.

props.synopsis: Politicians on the House Oversight Committee also request the Justice Department provide them with files and depositions from its investigation into the deceased financier.

title.children: Clintons among figures subpoenaed in US congressional Epstein probe

image.altText: A house in a large green field.

props.synopsis: Building a house on the wrong block of land does not happen very often, but it happens enough that some states and countries have laws in place to deal with it.Â

title.children: What the law says about building a house on the wrong block

image.altText: A Japanese man wearing a dark suit and blue 'Nuke Free' cap, smiling while standing next to a waterway

props.synopsis: Thousands of people are set to gather to commemorate the 80th anniversary and the catastrophic impacts of the nuclear bombing of Japan's Hiroshima during World War II, including survivors who are calling for the world to be free of atomic weapons.

title.children: Eight decades after the Hiroshima nuclear bombing, survivors have one demand

image.altText: A man carries a victim, their feet are seen as they carry them out.

props.synopsis: Surging floodwaters and a torrent of mud have swept through a village in the northern Indian Himalayan state of Uttarakhand.

title.children: Village washed away and several missing after flash floods in India

image.altText: Lots of screens, slightly blurred, featuring an AI human

props.synopsis: Standalone laws to govern artificial intelligence should only be considered as a last resort, the Productivity Commission warns, saying heavy-handed regulation could stifle AI's potential to add more than $116 billion to the economy over the next decade.

title.children: Productivity Commission warns against tough AI laws

image.altText: An underwater photo shows coral of varying colours, with fish swimming in between

props.synopsis: The Australian Institute of Marine Science says coral cover in the Great Barrier Reef has declined after mass bleaching events, with experts warning it faces a future of "increased volatility".Â

title.children: Great Barrier Reef coral cover decline shows 'ecosystem under stress'

image.altText: Two ibis on a fence.

props.synopsis: As we count down to discovering Australia's most underrated animal, there are plenty of worthy contenders that didn't make it into this year's top 10.

title.children: Australia has a love-hate relationship with the ibis, but the bird's not underrated

image.altText: netanyahu and trump shake hands while seated in the oval office

props.synopsis: Kenneth Roth is the former chief of Human Rights Watch, and he believes only the US president can stop Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu from waging war in Gaza.

title.children: 'One person' with leverage over Netanyahu must act, says former HRW boss

image.altText: Inside the historical Mortlock Wing of the State Library of South Australia.

props.synopsis: Adelaide's premier library has been recognised by the 1000 Libraries Awards as second most beautiful in the world, while Victoria has snagged seventh spot.

title.children: The Australian libraries among top 10 most beautiful in the world

image.altText: A rocky granite island in the ocean.

props.synopsis: When Tasmania broke away from New South Wales politically in the 19th century it was decided all islands south of Wilsons Promontory would belong to the new colony, but it didn't quite work out that way.

title.children: Charting bungle created 'land border' between Tasmania and Victoria

image.altText: A finger about to press the Youtube app button on a mobile phone.

props.synopsis: In a report released on Wednesday, Australia's internet watchdog said both YouTube and Apple had been unresponsive to questions about the number of reports of child abuse material on their platforms.

title.children: eSafety commissioner says YouTube 'turning a blind eye' to child abuse

image.altText: A wind turbine under construction at a remote mine site.

props.synopsis:
As many of its delegates pour significant investment into renewables systems, the keynote panel at this year's Diggers and Dealers conference suggests Australia's switch to a fully renewable grid is dead in the water.

Â

title.children: Major mining forum challenges Australia's 'zombie' energy transition

image.altText: Nibok refugee settlement on Nauru. It is a row of rectangular accommodation units.

props.synopsis: Australia is seeking to deport three people released under the NZYQ decision to the tiny Pacific nation in exchange for an undisclosed payment, but their removal has been stalled since February due to court challenges.

title.children: UN urges Australian government to halt deportation of man to Nauru

image.altText: Colourful sketched map with Latin writing at the top and many intersecting lines across the page.

props.synopsis: Cartographers in the 1600s had bold ideas of Australia, and some incredible methods of depicting those ideas in maps and globes.Â

title.children: 17th-century mapmakers had vivid ideas about Australia. They were wrong

image.altText: Man in suit (Macron) stands as a flem appears in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A man who stopped to light a cigarette from the fire at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier under the Arc de Triomphe in France has been arrested.

title.children: France arrests man who lit cigarette from war memorial flame

image.altText: A brown dog touches an elderly hand resting on bed, hand being held by a young person, white sheets.

props.synopsis: Neil Robinsonâs complex medical needs made the idea of him dying at home a daunting prospect for his family. Central Queensland's only hospice gave them another option.

title.children: Family says hospice provides next best option to dying at home

image.altText: A blonde woman speaks to the press

props.synopsis: The attorney general has directed prosecutors to launch a grand jury investigation into whether Barack Obama's administration manufactured intelligence on Russian intereference in the 2016 elections.Â

title.children: Pam Bondi orders grand jury investigation over Trump-Russia probe

image.altText: Grace Harris plays a pull shot in The Hundred cricket tournament.

props.synopsis: Australian stars Meg Lanning and Grace Harris hit 11 sixes between them as they kick off The Hundred tournament in England in powerful fashion.

title.children: Harris reveals dumplings and hand speed key to big hitting in The Hundred

image.altText: OceanGate Titan submersible floating at the surface of the ocean

props.synopsis: The US Coast Guard finds OceanGate's chief executive ignored warnings from employees and that the company 'actively retaliated' against those who spoke up.

title.children: Titan submersible's firm had 'reckless disregard for safety', report finds
